g.text: If the global annual mean fresh water budget is balanced, the accumulated integral of
should sum to 0 at the end of integration. For the OAGP-Dai dataset a value of 0.45
tive of a significant net freshening (
) while for CORE2-Dai a value of 0.05
again a net freshening but with a global fresh water budget closer to balanced. CMIP5 models considered here
are very close to balanced at their pre-industrial state (not shown) whilst most of them show a small global net
freshening over the historical period with the ensemble mean value being 0.11
Uncertainties stated concerning CMIP5 ensemble means are the
standard deviation of the ensemble (multimodel mean). Uncertainties stated concerning temporal means from
observational data (i.e. global spatial patterns of atmospheric fluxes, temperature, and salinity) or CMIP5 mean
uncertainties (i.e. average of individual model uncertainties) are the standard deviation of the yearly detrended
timeseries and uncertainties in linear trends are the standard error of a linear fit (least squares). Although CMIP5
results are not used to calibrate the method, CMIP5 spread is used to estimate the method uncertainty i.e. from
the standard deviation of inferred versus calculated water cycle change in Fig. 4a. Total uncertainty in
for the three observational datasets is calculated as the root mean square of the method uncertainty and the data
uncertainty in equation (1), which is consistent in the two types of uncertainty are normal. Data uncertainty is
derived from the standard error of the linear fit of
annual timeseries and the standard deviation of the mixing
temporal mean. Data uncertainty in the three observational datasets (~30–32% of the mean water
change) is higher than the method uncertainty (~22% of the mean water cycle change). Where a single observa-
tionally based estimate of water cycle change is stated it is the arithmetic mean of estimates based on the three
datasets and the uncertainty is the root mean square of their uncertainties. In most models the water cycle ampli-
tude increases very close to linearly from the late 1970 s to the end of 21st century following the global surface
warming. A more sophisticated fit taking into account the exponential nature of the CC relationship
used but since trends are small and uncertainties are quite large for simplicity a linear fit is applied.
Water cycle amplification rate (%) is defined as the water cycle ampli-
tude change (inferred from equation (1) for the observational estimates) divided by the climatological mean
water cycle amplitude (i.e. from long-term mean distribution of
simulations). We also express water cycle change as a water cycle sensitivity to global surface warming (%/°C;
amplification (%) per degree of global mean surface temperature rise (/°C) ) to compare our results with the CC
Challenges in quantifying changes in the global water cycle.
2. Held, I. M. & Soden, B. J. Robust responses of the hydrological cycle to global warming.
3. Allen, M. R. & Ingram, W. J. Constraints on future changes in climate and the hydrological cycle.
4. Durack, P. J., Wijffels, S. E. & Matear, R. J. Ocean salinities reveal strong global water cycle intensification during 1950 to 2000.
5. Trenberth, K. E., Smith, L., Qian, T., Dai, A. & Fasullo, J. Estimates of the Global Water Budget and Its Annual Cycle Using
6. Schanze, J. J., Schmitt, R. W. & Yu, L. L. The global oceanic fresh water cycle: A state‐of‐the‐art quantification.
7. Curry, R., Dickson, B. & Yashayaev, I. A change in the fresh water balance of the Atlantic Ocean over the past four decades.
8. Boyer, T. P., Levitus, S., Antonov, J. I., Locarnini, R. A. & Garcia, H. E. Linear trends in salinity for the World Ocean, 1955-1998.
9. Hosoda, S., Suga, T., Shikama, N. & Mizuno, K. Global surface layer salinity change detected by Argo and its implication for
10. Helm, K. P., Bindoff, N. L. & Church, J. A. Changes in the global hydrological-cycle inferred from ocean salinity.
11. Durack, P. J. & Wijffels, S. E. Fifty-year trends in global ocean salinities and their relationship to broad-scale warming.
Salinity changes in the World Ocean since 1950 in relation to changing surface fresh water fluxes.
13. Stott, P. A., Sutton, R. T. & Smith, R. T. D.M. Detection and attribution of Atlantic salinity changes.
Near-surface salinity as nature’s rain gauge to detect human influence on the tropical water cycle.
15. Pierce, D. W., Gleckler, P. J., Barnett, T. P., Santer, B. D. & Durack, P. J. The fingerprint of human‐induced changes in the ocean’s
16. Durack, P. J., Wijffels, S. E. & Gleckler, P. J. Long-term sea-level change revisited: the role of salinity.
Maintenance and broadening of the ocean’s salinity distribution by the water cycle.
18. Walin, G. A theoretical framework for the description of estuaries.
19. Walin, G. On the relation between sea-surface heat flow and thermal circulation in the ocean.
20. Ishii, M. & Kimoto, M. Reevaluation of historical ocean heat content variations with time-varying XBT and MBT depth bias
21. Good, S. A., Martin, M. J. & Rayner, N. A. EN4: quality controlled ocean temperature and salinity profiles and monthly objective
22. Taylor, K. E., Stouffer, R. J. & Meehl, G. A. An overview of CMIP5 and the experiment design.
23. Chou, C. & Neelin, J. D. Mechanisms of global warming impacts on regional tropical precipitation.
